title: U.S. Places Sanctions on Vessel, Companies for Delivering Venezuelan Oil to Cuba
summary: The Treasury Department said Cuba has helped contribute to the crisis in Venezuela. The U.S. government on Friday increased sanctions on Venezuela, blacklisting a vessel that transported oil from Venezuela to Cuba and the two companies operating in the oil sector of Venezuela that own and operate the vessel.

title: Entrenching the Obama Presidency
summary: A federal judge rules that Trump can't revoke Obama's oil drilling ban.. No branch of government can bind its successors. Yet a federal judge last week divined an exception to this constitutional axiom by enshrining a Barack Obama order walling off 128 million acres of the Arctic and eastern seaboard from oil and gas production. Behold how liberals are attempting to entrench the Obama Presidency.

title: Google's Advisory Board Crash and Burn
summary: A lesson in tolerance from the moralists in Mountain View.. A few years ago one could watch social-justice activists shouting at speakers on campus and conclude the country still has bigger problems than intolerant young progressives. Maybe it's time to start worrying. Witness the implosion of a new Google advisory board after an employee protest.

title: Recession False Alarm
summary: The job market shows underlying strength after February's scare.. Friday's solid labor report ought to ease fears that the U.S. economy is skidding toward recession. Employers added a healthy 196,000 jobs in March while unemployment held at 3.8%, confirming that the labor market continues to expand following a freeze in February and should continue despite economic problems abroad.

title: Hijacked in Hong Kong
summary: Now Beijing wants to extradite dissenters for trial in China.. A sad fact is that bad behavior that would be condemned in any other part of the world is ignored in China because the large Chinese market makes people think twice before speaking the obvious. So kudos to the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong and their business allies for speaking up against a proposal to let the territory start extraditing people China wants to put on trial.

title: Hip-Hop Artist Nipsey Hussle Promoted Job Skills and Investments
summary: Los Angeles recording artist worked to revive his neighborhood and link the inner city with Silicon Valley. Some hip-hop artists celebrate lifestyles revolving around fashion, flashy cars and flashier jewelry. Nipsey Hussle trafficked in some of that imagery but also included more unusual themes in his music: long-term investment and career development.

title: U.S. to Designate Iranian Guard Corps a Foreign Terror Group
summary: The designation, the first time any government entity will be branded as terrorist, will be accompanied by an alert to U.S. forces to warn of possible retaliation. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is preparing to designate Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a foreign terrorist organization, U.S. officials said, a step that would vastly escalate the American pressure campaign against Tehran but which has divided U.S. officials.

title: Boeing to Cut 737 MAX Production
summary: Aerospace giant also appoints a special board committee to examine its development of new planes. Boeing Co. will cut production of its 737 MAX by a fifth and appointed a special board committee to examine its development of new planes, as the financial impact from two crashes of its best-selling jetliner deepens.

title: Trump's Lawyer Urges IRS to Reject Democrats' Tax-Return Demand
summary: Attorney says turning over returns to Ways and Means chairman under longtime law 'would set a dangerous precedent'. WASHINGTON-A lawyer for President Trump said that House Democrats' request for the president's tax returns flouts constitutional constraints and should be rejected by the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Hedge-Fund Manager Bill Browder Calls for Top Level Staffing Changes at Swedbank as Chairman Resigns
summary: Resignation of Lars Idermark comes eight days after bank fired Chief Executive Birgitte Bonneson. A reputational crisis at Swedbank AB intensified Friday when the chairman of the Stockholm-based lender resigned, saying the continuing media attention around the bank conflicts with his role as chief executive of Swedish forestry group Södra.

title: Trump Says Southern-Border Asylum Seekers Are Running a 'Scam'
summary: President visits border area, says those requesting asylum make up stories of persecution; gang violence is still a problem in Central America. CALEXICO, Calif.-President Trump made his case for more barriers as he visited the border with Mexico on Friday, while continuing to say the U.S. immigration system is being overwhelmed by Central Americans seeking asylum.

title: Barr Orders LGBT Bias Probe Within Justice Department
summary: Bureau of Prisons, FBI accused of discrimination by group representing lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender employees. Attorney General William Barr has asked the federal Bureau of Prisons and the FBI to investigate allegations of discrimination against lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender Justice Department employees in their ranks.

title: Libyan Crisis Presents New Worry for White House-and Oil Markets
summary: The conflict increases the chance Washington will renew exemptions to buyers of Iran's sanctioned crude.. A mounting conflict in Libya is threatening to upset the global supply of oil at a time when prices are booming, and increases the likelihood that the U.S. will renew waivers for some buyers of Iranian oil, a U.S. official involved in the sanctions program said.

title: Judge to Hold Hearings on Decision to Allow CVS-Aetna Merger
summary: U.S. Judge Richard Leon will hear from witnesses including the American Medical Association in live testimony on the deal in May. WASHINGTON-A federal judge on Friday said he wants to hear in court from witnesses who object to the Justice Department's decision last year to approve CVS Health Corp.'s nearly $70 billion acquisition of Aetna Inc.-a highly unusual move that threatens to shake up the already-consummated deal.

title: The Score: The Business Week in 7 Stocks
summary: The Journal's weekly guide to the ups and downs of the business world. Major indexes finished the week with gains, thanks to midweek signs of progress in trade negotiations between the U.S. and China and a strong March jobs report from the Labor Department on Friday.

title: Why America Needs New Alliances
summary: The international order of the Cold War era no longer makes sense. But the world can't do without U.S. leadership. Here's a better approach.. President Trump is often accused of creating a needless rift with America's European allies. The secretary-general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Jens Stoltenberg, expressed a different view Thursday when he told a joint session of Congress: "Allies must spend more on defense-this has been the clear message from President Trump, and this message is having a real impact."

title: Trump's Dubious Prescription-Price Plan
summary: HHS repeats the Obama administration's mistake by trying to direct markets via regulation.. Drug manufacturers and pharmacy-benefit managers are bickering over who's to blame for rising prescription prices at the drugstore. At a Senate hearing in February, CEOs of seven drugmakers took turns lambasting PBMs, and on Tuesday the benefits managers will get the chance to defend themselves. As usual, the biggest culprit is government, which is why the Trump administration's plan to ameliorate the problem should be met with caution.

title: An Aircraft Bubble Epilogue
summary: How cheap money and strategic gamesmanship helped give birth to Boeing's 737 MAX.. To make sense of Thursday's press conference in Addis Ababa defending the actions of the crew aboard Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302, it may be wise to consider the views of a group of pilots and consultants interviewed by the Seattle Times.

title: Scott Walker's Gift to His Democratic Successor
summary: Unions called his labor reforms the end of the world. Now Wisconsin can't live without them.. In Arthur Conan Doyle's Sherlock Holmes mystery "The Adventure of Silver Blaze," the dog that didn't bark reveals the greater truth. The same might be said of Wisconsin Gov. Tony Evers's first state budget proposal. Derided by critics as a "liberal wish list," Mr. Evers's budget proposes to expand Medicaid, freeze school choice, overturn right to work, fund Planned Parenthood, add more than 700 government jobs, increase spending by $7 billion, and raise taxes by more than $1 billion.

title: Politics as Cartooning: What's Trump, Doc?
summary: Imagine Joe Biden as Pepé le Pew and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez as Popeye's girlfriend, Olive Oyl.. This is an age of cartoons-a time of intense exaggerations and exaggerated personalities. The president is a master cartoonist, with a gift for caricature and ridicule: "Crooked Hillary," "Lyin' Ted," "Little Rocket Man," and so on. His instincts are hyperbolic. Not long ago he lampooned the House Intelligence Committee chairman as "Little Pencil-Neck Adam Schiff." His most interesting cartoon is himself, a work entirely of his own contriving, with a touch of the Tasmanian Devil.

title: Notable & Quotable: 'Beckys'
summary: 'Critical Becky Studies: Critical Explorations of Gender, Race, and the Pedagogies of Whiteness.'. Max Eden writing for City Journal, April 5:

title: Boeing Identifies Second Software Issue on 737 MAX
summary: Boeing has been scrutinizing the software on the 737 MAX after the Ethiopian Airlines crash. Boeing Co. has identified a second software problem that must be resolved as part of an overall fix to get its 737 MAX airliners flying again, even as new details emerged about escalating U.S.-Ethiopian friction over investigating a crash of the jet last month.

title: Members of Purdue Pharma's Sackler Family Leave Nonprofit Board
summary: Kathe Sackler and Mortimer D.A. Sackler no longer serving on board of the New York Academy of Sciences. Certain members of the Sackler family, which owns OxyContin-maker Purdue Pharma LP, are leaving governing boards of prominent nonprofit organizations as some of the Sackler family face scrutiny for their alleged role in sparking the nation's opioid crisis.

title: California Files Suit in New Challenge to Emissions Rollback
summary: Move targets EPA and NHTSA, escalating state's battle with Trump administration. WASHINGTON-California is escalating its battle with the Trump administration over cars and climate change, filing suit Friday to demand that two federal agencies release data they used to justify a rollback of auto emissions standards.

title: U.S. Dollar Ends Week With Gains
summary: Employment report shows hiring rebounded in March. The U.S. dollar rose to one of its highest levels of the year as the latest jobs report showed that hiring bounced back in March, spurring confidence in the health of the domestic economy.

title: Trump Urges Fed to Cut Rates, Resume Bond Purchases
summary: 'In terms of quantitative tightening, it should absolutely now be quantitative easing.'. President Trump on Friday repeated his call for the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates and said it should restart buying assets to stimulate growth.

title: Retailer Fred's Hires Adviser as It Tries to Turn Around Business
summary: Struggling regional discount chain with 600 stores in the South considering more closures. Discount retailer Fred's Inc. has hired a financial adviser as it looks to downsize its store footprint and turn around its business, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Sequoia Capital Partner Michael Dixon Leaving the Firm
summary: Mr. Dixon, an investor in Clover Health and Health Catalyst, will focus on health care. Michael Dixon, a longtime partner at Sequoia Capital who concentrated on health care and growth-stage deals, is moving on after a 10-year run.

title: Plan to End Drug Rebates Adds Protections for Insurers
summary: Administration's move to backstop losses could prevent premiums from rising significantly. The Trump administration said the federal government would offer a risk-sharing system to reimburse health insurers for financial losses resulting from a proposed ban on certain pharmaceutical-industry rebates in Medicare.

title: Health-Care Executive Found Guilty in Fraud Case
summary: Philip Esformes was convicted of money laundering and conspiracy to defraud the U.S.. A Florida man linked to the college-admissions scandal was found guilty in a separate case Friday on 20 charges in what the Justice Department called its largest criminal health-care-fraud case.

title: 'The Workshop and the World' Review: Science and Authority
summary: Ten trailblazers who confronted opposition when arguing the case for scientiﬁc facts.. Eppur si muove ("And yet it moves"): These are the words Galileo purportedly whispered when facing the Inquisition in 1633, having recanted his heretical view that Earth circles the sun. The apocryphal utterance has come to represent the defiance of science in the face of religious, societal or governmental opposition. The notion of scientific authority-of argument rooted in experimental facts as opposed to unsubstantiated opinion-was something new in Galileo's time. In succeeding centuries, the Enlightenment ideal of a systematic, self-correcting method to illuminate the organization and operations of nature would give rise to a caste of knowledge workers whose secular evangelists would preach the virtues of scientific investigation.

title: 'Solid Seasons' Review: A Transcendental Affinity
summary: Even early in the friendship, the assumed roles of Emerson as mentor and Thoreau as student were often inverted.. More than a century and a half after his death, Henry David Thoreau looms larger in the American consciousness than ever. His detailed reflections on plants, weather and the turn of the seasons in 19th-century Concord, Mass., helped shape modern environmental thought. Today, in a culture where mental and physical decluttering has become trendy, many see the appeal of Thoreau's experiment in scaled-down living, celebrated in "Walden." And Thoreau's worry over the speed and distraction of emerging technology chimes neatly with our prevailing anxieties about social media.

title: 'Hate' Review: The New Terror in France
summary: There is an unsettling wave of anti-Semitism sweeping across France, made more potent by the willful denial surrounding it.. In 2015, President Obama was asked if the media overstates the threat of terrorism. "It is entirely legitimate," he replied, "for the American people to be deeply concerned when you've got a bunch of violent, vicious zealots who behead people or randomly shoot a bunch of folks in a deli in Paris." This was weeks after a self-declared Islamic State sympathizer went on a rampage and killed four people at a French kosher supermarket. Confused by the president's apparent attempt to diminish what appeared to be a purposefully anti-Semitic act, a journalist later asked for clarification. "The adverb that the president chose," explained White House press secretary Josh Earnest, "was used to indicate that the individuals who were killed in that terrible tragic incident were killed not because of who they were, but because of where they randomly happened to be."

title: Libyan Warlord Launches Assault to Capture Nation's Capital
summary: The assault on Tripoli is a turning point in Libya's struggles since the fall of Gadhafi. CAIRO-A renegade Libyan military commander launched an offensive to capture the capital Tripoli, raising the risk of a full-blown civil war in the oil-rich North African country on Europe's doorstep.

title: S&P 500 Closes Higher for Seventh Straight Session
summary: Jobs report comes in largely as expected; Trump signals trade progress with China. The S&P 500 climbed for the seventh trading session in a row after a positive but largely as-expected jobs report, capping a quiet week of trading in which stocks crept higher.

title: 'Where's the Recession?'
summary: The challenge of selling socialism in a thriving economy.. That headline is the question posed this morning by Fox Business Network colleague Maria Bartiromo after U.S. job creation beat expectations in the Labor Department's March employment report. Despite concerns about slowing economic growth, U.S. firms keep on hiring. The resilient American jobs machine also poses a political question: If the economy doesn't fall into recession, will Democrats need a new message for 2020?

title: The Smallest Guy on the Court Plays a Big Role for Virginia
summary: Freshman Kihei Clark doesn't have flashy numbers, but the 5-foot-9 guard is often tasked with pressuring the opposing team's top ballhandlers. A quick glance at Kihei Clark's numbers would make you think the 5-foot-9 freshman is just a bit player in Virginia's Final Four run. He averages 4.4 points, 2.4 rebounds and 2.5 assists per game. He shoots 34.5% from the field and 32.5% from 3-point range.

title: Legalization in Canada Sparks Rally in Marijuana Stocks
summary: Big beverage makers also jump into the fray, hoping to capitalize on growth. Shares of marijuana companies have been on a tear this year, a sign that the cannabis craze isn't letting up.

title: Global Antitrust Agencies Issue New Rules on Enforcement
summary: International Competition Network protocol, backed by U.S., aims to set procedural norms; China's likely response unknown. WASHINGTON-A new set of principles aims to make the process by which antitrust laws are enforced more transparent, predictable and consistent across international jurisdictions.

title: Former Lobbyist Involved in Bribery Scheme Gets Five Years Probation
summary: Todd Howe pleaded guilty to eight counts in 2016, agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. A former Albany lobbyist with close ties to the administration of New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo was sentenced Friday to five years probation.

title: The World Seems to Have Dodged Recession, for Now
summary: Strong U.S. jobs growth and other global data suggest last year's panic was misplaced. If the world was at risk of sliding into recession, policy makers appear to have pivoted in time to prevent it.

title: U.S. Government Bonds Gain After Tame Wage Data
summary: Some investors read slower wage growth as a signal tight labor market isn't fueling inflation. U.S. government-bond prices rose Friday after the Labor Department said average hourly earnings rose less in March than the month before, dampening inflation concerns.

title: FAA Disputes Allegations of Lapses on 737 MAX Training
summary: Agency tells Senate committee that employees were qualified to set mandates on grounded Boeing jet. The acting chief of the Federal Aviation Administration has told lawmakers there were no systemic problems with the qualifications of key agency staff who helped establish pilot-training mandates for Boeing Co. 's grounded 737 MAX jet.

title: Hiring Rebounded in March, Helping Ease Downturn Jitters
summary: The unemployment rate held steady at 3.8%, just above a 49-year low touched last fall. WASHINGTON-U.S. hiring sprang back in March, showing a slowdown in February was likely just a passing chill during a historically long stretch of job creation.

title: Biden Makes Light of Controversy Over Unwanted Touching
summary: Former vice president also reiterates he will be more mindful of personal space, says he is close to 2020 decision. WASHINGTON-Joe Biden made light of the controversy over allegations that he touched women in unwelcome ways, saying at a labor conference Friday that he had permission to hug a top union leader and put his arm around a boy.

title: Oil Hits Five-Month Highs on Economic Optimism
summary: Prices climb after data showed the U.S. economy added 196,000 jobs in March, exceeding economist expectations. • Oil prices climbed to five-month highs Friday, boosted by economic data that showed strong growth in U.S. jobs.

title: Photos of the Week: Algeria's President Resigns, Garfield Beach Mystery Solved
summary: British companies hoard supplies, Algeria's president resigns, Garfield beach mystery solved and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Taking the Visitor by the Hand
summary: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's entrance pavilion is building designed to be experienced as a sequential unfolding of interrelated masses, spaces and vistas.. Back when the academic tradition ruled training in architecture, one of the most important concepts imparted to students at the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris was the art's processional aspect, or what the French call la marche: the experience of a building as a sequential unfolding of interrelated masses, spaces and vistas. It is not easy to think of a finer manifestation of this concept than the Metropolitan Museum of Art's central entrance pavilion, with its majestic façade, Great Hall, grand staircase and balcony. The principal architect of this stupendous New York ensemble, which opened in 1902, was Richard Morris Hunt (1827-1895), the first American to attend the École.

title: May Requests Further Brexit Delay
summary: Any extension would require unanimous agreement by the 27 leaders of the other EU countries. The British government has requested an additional delay to Brexit until June 30 to buy more time to get a divorce deal through Parliament, as the European Union discussed offering a longer postponement of up to a year.

title: Gold Inches Higher After Jobs Report
summary: Employment data beats expectations, boosting confidence in economy. Gold prices swung between small gains and losses before closing slightly higher Friday, wobbling after a stronger-than-expected jobs report lifted confidence in the U.S. economy.

title: Responding to Gov. Cuomo on Tax Fairness
summary: The 2017 tax bill increased the progressivity of our tax regime by reducing one of the largest "tax expenditures" that disproportionately benefits those in the top brackets. Those taxpayers are now paying more to support our federal government. The additional federal revenue isn't coming from the state of New York. It's coming from wealthy taxpayers.. Gov. Andrew Cuomo's April 2 letter "Cuomo: Florida Gets Welfare From New York" in response to Florida Sen. Rick Scott's "Why New Yorkers Flee For Florida" (op-ed, March 21) is premised on the notion that New York is a "donor" state, giving the federal government "$36 billion more" than it gets back. States don't pay taxes to the federal government-taxpayers do. They do so under a highly progressive regime in which the wealthy pay far more than others. The reason that more money flows to the federal government from New York than from, say, Mississippi is because far more wealthy people with far higher incomes live in New York.

title: Man Who Allegedly Claimed to Be Missing Boy Timmothy Pitzen Is Charged
summary: Authorities say suspect learned about disappearance of Timmothy from recently broadcast news program. Federal authorities charged an Ohio man with lying to a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent after he allegedly claimed Wednesday to be Timmothy Pitzen, a then-6-year-old boy from Illinois who disappeared in 2011.

title: Trump Nominee Malpass Selected as Next World Bank President
summary: The former undersecretary of the Treasury for international affairs has been a critic of the international development bank. President Donald Trump's choice to be the next World Bank president, David Malpass, was formally approved on Friday by a unanimous vote of the bank's board of executive directors in Washington.

title: Dealing With Measles Vaccination Deniers
summary: Perhaps if we stop worrying about our political agendas and concentrate on the health of our children, we will no longer read headlines about children needlessly being infected with preventable illnesses.. "Measles Cases Already Top Last Year's Total" (U.S. News, April 2) illustrates that vaccines' success in nearly eradicating many viruses has made us less vigilant, opening the door to the reintroduction of some life-threatening diseases as people forget how ruthless these viruses are. Vaccinations have been one of the most effective public-health implementations over the past century. As a millennial, I never experienced the scare of polio, and I don't have a burning image of a family member being placed in an iron lung. I didn't live through the Spanish influenza pandemic. When it comes to health care, I'm a firm believer in small government. However, the steps lawmakers have taken to reduce vaccine exemptions and enforce vaccination requirements are necessary to prevent further damage from the public's amnesia.

title: Two Residential Standards
summary: It's interesting that Sens. Dianne Feinstein and Kamala Harris object to Daniel Bress's nomination to the federal bench because he lives in Washington, D.C., and not California, though he is from California and a member of the California bar.. Regarding your editorial "A Ninth Circuit Test for the White House" (March 30): It's interesting that Sens. Dianne Feinstein and Kamala Harris object to Daniel Bress's nomination to the federal bench because he lives in Washington, D.C., and not California, though he is from California and a member of the California bar. I don't remember the Democratic pooh-bahs complaining about Hillary Clinton running for the U.S. Senate seat in New York in 2000, although she had never lived there.

title: 'Ben-Hur' Creator Foretold New Mexico's Money Woes
summary: "All calculations based on our experience elsewhere fail in New Mexico.". Stephen Ford's "Albuquerque's Electric Bus Takes a Wrong Turn and Goes Nowhere" (Cross Country, March 30) reminds this former Albuquerque resident of the words of territorial Gov. Lew Wallace in 1881. The author of "Ben-Hur" and Civil War hero wrote to his wife back home in Indiana: "All calculations based on our experience elsewhere fail in New Mexico." The debate after 138 years is still whether this was a prophecy or a curse.

title: Bridgewater Founder's Foundation Donates $100 Million to Connecticut
summary: State's largest gift to go to education and entrepreneurial programs. Dalio Philanthropies, run by the founder of the world's largest hedge fund, announced Friday it was giving Connecticut a $100 million donation for education and entrepreneurial programs, the largest gift ever for the state.

title: The Stages of AirPods: Denial, Acceptance, Worship
summary: Have I gotten hooked on pumping voices into my own head?. There are three key stages in the life of an AirPods owner. The first stage, of course, is horror: How could anyone wear those ghastly, bright white Apple earbuds? They make a person look like they have Styrofoam packing peanuts jammed into the sides of their head. Are we just going to be OK about this? The whole world is going to hell. I need a drink. Two drinks.

title: Fashion Marketplace Poshmark Preps to Go Public This Fall
summary: Social fashion marketplace generated $150 million in revenue last year. Fashion resale marketplace Poshmark Inc. is preparing to file for an initial public offering that could come as soon as this fall, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Norway Cuts Emerging-Market Bonds From Its Sovereign-Wealth Fund
summary: Move marks country's latest effort to distance its economy from global energy sector. Norway's $1 trillion sovereign-wealth fund is set to slash its holdings of emerging-market bonds, a move closely watched by other investors given the fund's massive size.

title: Truckers Cut Payrolls As Freight Demand Softens
summary: Hiring in broader logistics slows as red-hot growth pace of 2018 cools down. Trucking companies pulled back from hiring in March as freight demand softened and job growth across the logistics sector slowed.

title: The Best Ways to Appeal College-Aid Offers
summary: You can get better financial-aid packages from prospective colleges-if you know how to ask. Financial-aid packages are arriving on students' doorsteps, and the big question many students and parents ask is a simple one: Can I get a better deal?

title: Casting a Negative Light on Motel 6
summary: The chain has paid a fine and agreed to stop providing information on guests without a warrant, but now it needs to work on quality. "We'll leave the light on for you" goes the famous advertising slogan of Motel 6. While radio personality Tom Bodett's folksy line has worked wonders for the roadside budget chain, now owned by G6 Hospitality, it might well be "we'll leave the lights on so the authorities can find and deport you."

title: Prominent Lawyer to Plead Guilty in College-Admissions Scandal
summary: Gordon Caplan is the highest-profile parent to indicate such a plea in case. The former co-chairman of a top U.S. law firm said he plans to plead guilty for his role in the college admissions cheating scandal-the highest-profile parent yet to admit to committing fraud in trying to bolster a child's application to an elite college.

title: Sen. Elizabeth Warren Calls for Ending Senate Filibuster Rule
summary: Democratic presidential hopeful backs proposal endorsed by progressive activists and President Trump, but scorned by many congressional leaders of both parties. NEW YORK-Sen. Elizabeth Warren on Friday said she supported ending the filibuster in the U.S. Senate should Democrats win back the White House, arguing that Republicans have reaped the most benefit from both parties' efforts in recent years to change the chamber's procedural rules.

title: Jessica Yellin Has Stories to Tell
summary: With a novel and a social-media venture, a former CNN correspondent hopes to fight the 'outrage fatigue' of cable news-and sexism in the workplace. Jessica Yellin, the former CNN White House correspondent, has found an unusual way to deliver an exposé of her old industry.

title: One Man's Great Leap: From Gobi Desert Farmer to International Deal Maker
summary: China's Cultural Revolution made Weijian Shan a laborer in the name of Communism. Now he operates at the pinnacle of capitalism.. Weijian Shan has had spectacular success as a U.S.-trained economist and a dogged private-equity deal maker. Perhaps more remarkable is that he has had a career at all.

title: Gold Badges and Boozy Breakfasts: Inside the Frenetic Fight for IPO Listings
summary: Resume Subscription. When BJ's Wholesale Club Holdings Inc. was planning its IPO last year, a team from Nasdaq Inc. descended on its headquarters in Westborough, Mass., to try to persuade it to list on the exchange.

title: Fiat Chrysler Settles Lawsuit Over Sales Reporting
summary: Justice Department and SEC probes remain ongoing. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV settled a lawsuit brought by an Illinois dealership group that accused the auto maker of pressuring it to manipulate monthly vehicle sales reports.

title: Overcoming the Labor of Calculation
summary: Inventors tried many times over the centuries to build an effective portable calculator-but no one succeeded until John Merryman.. The world owes a debt of gratitude to Jerry Merryman, who died on Feb. 27 at the age of 86. It was Merryman who, in 1965, worked with two other engineers at Texas Instruments to invent the world's first pocket calculator. Today we all carry powerful calculators on our smartphones, but Merryman was the first to solve a problem that had plagued mathematicians at least since Gottfried Leibniz, one of the creators of calculus in the 17th century, who observed: "It is unworthy of excellent men to lose hours like slaves in the labor of calculation, which could safely be relegated to anyone else if machines were used."

title: You Pay for Netflix and Spotify Monthly. What About Financial Planning?
summary: Charles Schwab just launched a service that could send a shock wave through the financial-planning world. How you pay for financial advice can be as important as how much you pay.

title: Equality for Women Must Start at Home (Even the Gates Home)
summary: Unpaid work is the often invisible labor that keeps households running. Everywhere in the world, women do more of it than men. A few years ago, as I was starting to study the household burdens of the world's poorest women, a colleague in our foundation's India office told me about meeting Champa. She was a 22-year-old mother who lived in a tribal region of central India. Her daughter, Rani, was dying of acute malnutrition. The situation was desperate but not hopeless: There was a treatment center only a few hours away.

title: Stock Investors Should Love This Jobs Report
summary: Friday's jobs report makes the Fed's stance look way too cautious, but since it won't get more hawkish any time soon, the situation for stock investors looks promising. What slowdown?

title: Five Best: Susan Page on Books About First Ladies
summary: The author, most recently, of 'The Matriarch: Barbara Bush and the Making of an American Dynasty' recommends works about the workings of the East Wing.. Edited by Margaret A. Hogan and C. James Taylor (2014)

title: Netanyahu Trails Rival Days Before Israeli Elections
summary: The prime minister made a final plea to voters to get behind his Likud party ahead of elections April 9. TEL AVIV-Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is trailing his main rival in most final polls ahead of elections next week, but his challenger, a former general, looks unlikely to be able to cobble together enough support from other parties to form a government.

title: 'Martin Buber' Review: The Hebrew Humanist
summary: Buber loved the parables of the Hassidic masters, tales that hallowed the everyday, that refused to cleave the sacred from the secular.. One afternoon in 1914, Franz Kafka visited the Berlin home of the philosopher and teacher Martin Buber. Kafka came to solicit the sage's advice on the workings of divine justice. More than four decades later, the 16-year-old daughter of Israeli Gen. Moshe Dayan came to Buber's house in Jerusalem to ask how young, secular Israelis like herself could be nourished, as she said, by "knowledge and love of Jewish culture and the Bible." These oracle-seekers-one from an insecure diaspora about to vanish, the other from a new nation-state freeing its people from the fetters of exile-frame the life of one of the 20th century's great spiritual leaders.

title: Mysteries: Auf Wiedersehen, Mr. Kerr
summary: One last job for Bernie Gunther, the Philip Marlowe of interwar Berlin.. If you've never read one of Philip Kerr's moody, historical procedurals, today is not too late to start. "March Violets" (1989) introduced Bernhard "Bernie" Gunther, a hard-boiled Berlin police detective busy investigating underworld offenders while even greater criminals-the Nazis-rise to power all around him. "The Pale Criminal" (1990) and "A German Requiem" (1991) traced his further adventures. (These first three works can-and should-be read in a single volume, "Berlin Noir.") Later books in the series, like "Field Grey" (2010) and "Prussian Blue" (2017), hopped through time from the 1930s to the 1950s. Now "Metropolis" (Putnam, 368 pages, $28) takes us further back than ever before, to 1928. It's the 14th book in the acclaimed series-and the last. Kerr died last year after completing this worthy auf Wiedersehen.

title: Fiction: Stubbornly Persistent Illusions
summary: A search for a ripple in space-time becomes a symbol of how lives are changed by forces we cannot see.. In her novel "Lost and Wanted" (Knopf, 316 pages, $26.95), Nell Freudenberger relates the momentous 2015 discovery by a team of physicists of a gravitational wave, a ripple in the fabric of space-time produced by the collision of two black holes over a billion years ago. For scientists, the breakthrough further confirmed Einstein's theory of General Relativity, but for Ms. Freudenberger's purposes it doubles as a symbol of the forces that occur just beyond the scope of our perception. What other wonders might we be missing simply because, for the moment, we lack the instruments to detect them?

title: 'The Good Wife' Star Julianna Margulies Lists Soho Home for $5.75 Million
summary: The actress is moving to a larger home in Manhattan for her family.. Actress Julianna Margulies is listing her modern apartment in New York's Soho neighborhood for $5.75 million.

title: 'Foursome' and 'Alfred Stieglitz' Review: The Intimate Gallerist
summary: As photographer and impresario, Alfred Stieglitz changed the story of American art and the lives of dozens of artists.. Spring brings us not one but two new books focusing on the enormous achievements and remarkable personality of Alfred Stieglitz. Given their different aims, both books can profitably and pleasurably be read side by side, and certainly Stieglitz deserves this degree of attention, in this or any other season.

title: Children's Books: A Child's Garden of Verses
summary: Christina Rosetti's memorable poetry is a vivid way to introduce verse to young readers during Poetry Month, and an illustrated Rossetti volume is among the children's books Meghan Cox Gurdon writes about this week.. On the morning of May 30, 1431, a teenage girl was tied to a stake in the French city of Rouen and burned alive before a massive crowd. Joan of Arc was 19. In a stunning collection of poems, "Voices" (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 195 pages, $17.99), David Elliott takes adolescent readers into the last hours of the Catholic peasant also known as the Maid of Orléans, who rose from obscurity to lead an army against the occupying English during the Hundred Years' War.

title: The Machines That Will Read Your Mind
summary: Ever more sophisticated brain scans are combining with artificial intelligence to produce tools that can track thoughts, test truthfulness and someday, perhaps, download our very selves. When magnetic resonance imaging came into common use in the 1980s, it made the human brain visible in ways it had never been before. For the first time, we could see the soft brain tissue of a living subject, at a level of detail that could be observed previously only in autopsies. For doctors trying to help patients whose brains were damaged or diseased, MRI provided an invaluable snapshot of their condition.

title: Apple Music Overtakes Spotify in Paid U.S. Subscribers
summary: Tech giant's subscription service trails Swedish rival's globally but is growing faster. Apple Music has surpassed Spotify Technology SA in paid U.S. subscriptions, according to people familiar with the matter, in a shift that escalates the music rivals' contest for listeners world-wide.

summary: The cloud company's CEO and co-founder, Aaron Levie, says some of his best advice has come from reaching out randomly to inspiring business minds; 'worst-case scenario is you don't get a response'. Chief executive, Box Inc.

title: Pittsburgh Lawyer Milton Fine Invested in Motel and Found a Calling
summary: Purchase of Erie, Pa., property began a hotel-management business he eventually sold for $2.1 billion. It seemed like a minor deal in 1962 when Milton Fine, a Pittsburgh lawyer, and a partner invested in a motel near the entrance to Presque Isle State Park in Erie, Pa. Then the manager of the 41-unit Capri Motel died, leaving Mr. Fine and his partner, Edward A. Perlow, to run the business.

title: Eunetta T. Boone, Creator of 'One on One' Sitcom, Strove to Avoid Stereotypes
summary: Former sportswriter jumped to Hollywood after writing her first script and shining at a Warner Brothers workshop. As a writer and producer of television sitcoms about African-Americans, Eunetta T. Boone aimed to get laughs without demeaning her characters or reinforcing stereotypes.

title: All About That Grape? There's More to Understanding Wine
summary: Once upon a time, American wine labels didn't even identify grapes. Now, many oenophiles focus on certain varieties so narrowly that they fail to appreciate all a wine can be. WE LIVE IN a grape-centric age, when a grape variety is more than just a name on a label. For some wine drinkers, it's a means of self-definition. I've heard people declare "I'm a Pinot Noir person" or "I'm a Cabernet man" in much the same way they might express allegiance to a sports team. This phenomenon operates in reverse, too. "I'm not a Chardonnay drinker" is the most common anti-grape statement; Syrah tends to rank as most-disliked runner-up.

title: March Jobs Report Should Prompt Sighs of Relief From Fed Officials
summary: Evidence of solid job and low unemployment should bolster decision last month to hold interest rates steady. The strong March employment report should allow Federal Reserve officials to breathe a sigh of relief by showing that weak payroll growth in February was an aberration and not the start of a more serious economic slowdown.

title: Brick by Brick, Baltimore's Blighted Houses Get a New Life
summary: Resume Subscription. BALTIMORE-Five decrepit row houses that have stood for more than a century in West Baltimore will soon be gone-but not quite forgotten.

title: The Deep Rot Exposed by the Biden Flap
summary: The problem isn't too much hugging but the rancor and triviality of our political debate. Imagine for a moment you're the ruler of China. You've got a master plan to run the world.

title: How a Robotic Tail Could Help Future Space Travelers
summary: Researchers at the MIT Media Lab are developing technology for a day when amateur astronauts travel into orbit. Astronauts train for life in microgravity, where small movements create momentum and stasis requires handholds and tethers. The concepts of "floor" and "ceiling" cease to be meaningful. As the day approaches when extra-planetary travel becomes more accessible (at least, initially, to billionaire space tourists), researchers are developing tools to ease the transition to weightless living.

title: Prepaid-Card Users Get Protection Guarantee
summary: Consumer-finance agency mandates that services cover fraud, unauthorized charges and errors. WASHINGTON-Prepaid payment cards and mobile services just received a status upgrade, giving their users the same protections and services as those for bank debit-card customers.

summary: Ahead of the fair in Milan, see WSJ. Magazine's top picks, including statement wallpaper, silk rugs and luxe baskets. This wallpaper, part of the Muse collection created by British designer Faye Toogood for New York-based Calico Wallpaper, eliminates the need to hang up any art. Viewers can immerse themselves in Toogood's stunning designs, the colors of which were created with legendary women like Marie Curie and Coco Chanel in mind.

title: Canada Employment Down Slightly in March
summary: Economy lost a net 7,200 jobs last month, below expectations. Unemployment rate unchanged at 5.8%.. OTTAWA-Canada's jobs market contracted slightly in March, coming in below expectations after two months of strong gains.

title: A Final Four Mystery Unraveled: Why UVA and Auburn Have the Same Team Colors
summary: Resume Subscription. Auburn University and the University of Virginia, who meet in the Final Four of the NCAA tournament this weekend, have two more things in common. The first is their school colors: orange and blue. The second is how they came to wear those colors: through petty theft.

title: Hang Your Art With a Pro's Eye
summary: Expert installers on getting the most out of your art, be it an impressive collection or priceless family photos. EVEN THE most DIY-challenged can manage the basic hook, nail and wire combo that costs less than a latte. But art placement presents a bigger challenge-how to best show your collection. You want your walls to invite reflection, not vertigo. "Ninety-nine percent of people can physically hang art," said Adam Shultz, an artist, contractor and professional picture hanger in Yonkers, N.Y., "but that doesn't mean they know how to hang it properly."

title: The Bali That's Worth the Trek
summary: For the quintessential island experience, skip the trendy spots, and seek out these four character-filled hotels. Plus: A few stylish suggestions on what to wear in Bali. IN THE EARLY 1990s, I spent a semester in college studying on the island of Bali. I seldom went to the beach. Back then, although the backpackers and cheap-package tourists would often end up in Kuta on the south coast, island regulars would head inland to Ubud, the cultural heart of Bali. That's where you'd nearly always hear hypnotic gamelan music in the background, drifting in from ceremonies or temples. And traffic would stop to make way for women walking down the street in procession, wearing traditional dress-lace kebaya blouses and batik sarongs-balancing baskets of artfully layered fruit, flowers and other temple offerings on their heads.

summary: The city's hippest stripe epitomizes its upscale artistic scene. Augustus Bistro For eclectic fare in an opulent space, look no further than this recently reopened eatery that's tucked in a century-old post office building.augustusbistro.co.nz

title: Luxury Getaway Company Vik Retreats Expands
summary: This spring, Carrie and Alex Vik are introducing their first European property and a collection of bungalows at their hotel in Chile. Carrie and Alex Vik, art-loving hoteliers known for a handful of South American retreats, are expanding their business-on two fronts. Starting a decade ago, the couple helped put the Uruguayan beach town of José Ignacio on global travelers' maps with their trio of invitingly intimate properties: Estancia Vik, Playa Vik and Bahia Vik. They brought a similar sensibility to the Vik Chile hotel and Viña Vik winery, which they opened in 2014 on 11,000 acres in the Millahue Valley.

title: Baseball's Worst Hitter Still Hasn't Hit Bottom
summary: After hitting .168 last season, Orioles slugger Chris Davis is closing in on the longest hitless streak of all time. The last time we checked in on Chris Davis, things weren't going so hot. He was about halfway through what turned out to be one of the worst seasons in baseball history.

title: The Final Four Star Who Is Also Paying Off Student Loans
summary: Kenny Goins turned down scholarship offers from smaller schools to fulfill his dream of playing at Michigan State. Kenny Goins decided that he wanted to attend Michigan State at the age of 5, when he went to a Spartans basketball game and snapped a photograph of Magic Johnson from atop his dad's shoulders. His family laughed at his proclamation, but at that moment, Goins insisted with absolute certainty that his future would bring him back to East Lansing.

title: At Snapchat, the Kids Are All Right
summary: Snapchat doubled down on its youth demographic, but are their pockets deep enough to drive profits?. If Snapchat parent Snap Inc. were in high school, it might be crowned prom king. That doesn't mean it is going to find popularity after graduation.

title: Beijing's Bank Bailout Better Be Bold
summary: To revive growth, China needs to take potentially painful steps to reform its interest-rate system. The cash needed to patch the holes in Chinese banks' balance sheets probably isn't far from the half-trillion-dollar U.S. government bank bailout after the financial crisis. But that staggering sum alone may be only the beginning of the pain.

title: Are Far-Right Extremist Crimes Rising? No
summary: Terrorism is ticking up, but hate crimes and related violence have been steady since at least 1970. Recently, President Trump said he doesn't believe white nationalism is a growing problem-and at home in the U.S., he's right.

title: Mexico Struggles With Surge in Central American Migrants
summary: A softening of the country's migration policies along with a severe drought in Guatemala account for a bulk of the increase. Mexico is struggling to contain a surge of Central American migrants making their way to the U.S. border that has been fueled by a softening of Mexican migration policies and a severe drought in Guatemala.

title: Ad Spending Hits a New High as Search Ads, Out-of-Home and Amazon Rise
summary: Amazon more than doubled its ad revenue in 2018, new report says. Marketers drove U.S. advertising spending to a new peak last year, fueled by several large ad events-the Winter Olympics, the World Cup and the midterm elections-as well as demand for keyword-search and out-of-home ads.

title: Eurozone Releases Funds for Greece After Dispute Over Reforms
summary: Policy tensions remain, including over Athens' lenient treatment of taxpayers who owe the state money. Eurozone governments approved the release of €1 billion ($1.1 billion) of funds for Greece, after a monthslong spat over whether the country is reneging on the economic overhauls that it promised when its bailout ended.

title: Samsung Hopes Strong Chip Sales Aren't Just a Memory
summary: Demand has dried up in recent months, deflating prices for two major types of memory chips. SEOUL-Smartphone maker Samsung Electronics Co. has been relying largely on producing chips to make money. But now it has made too much of a good thing.

title: Saudi Arabia Detains More Activists Despite International Criticism
summary: This is the kingdom's first crackdown since the murder of dissident journalist Jamal Khashoggi. Saudi Arabia has detained at least eight more people, including two U.S. citizens, who pressed for women's rights in the highly conservative kingdom, deepening a crackdown on political opponents despite international criticism.

title: The $26 Million Question: What Happens if You Don't File Your Taxes for a Decade?
summary: The IRS can fill out a substitute return for you-and it usually isn't accurate. And a lot of penalties and interest will accrue.. Even if you don't go to jail, blowing off the Internal Revenue Service is a really bad idea.

title: Americans Hate Social Media but Can't Give It Up, Poll Finds
summary: Poll finds a majority across the political spectrum also says social media wastes time and spreads falsehoods-even as 70% check in daily. WASHINGTON-Americans have a paradoxical attachment to the social-media platforms that have transformed communication, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds, saying they regard services such as Facebook to be divisive and a threat to privacy but continue to use them daily.

title: Bankruptcies Test One of Wall Street's Favorite Trades
summary: The grounding of Boeing's 737 MAX jet may give aircraft lessors a short-term lift, but they also face a worrying flood of planes coming into the market. When aviation authorities order more than 300 Boeing planes to be grounded, it should be party time for aircraft leasing companies and their Wall Street backers. Unfortunately, a recent string of airline bankruptcies gives them too much else to worry about.

title: Carlos Ghosn to Stay Behind Bars for at Least 10 Days
summary: The former auto executive had earlier been arrested on fresh suspicions of financial misconduct. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn will be held in jail until at least April 14 without possibility of bail, a Tokyo court said Friday.

title: Mnuchin Puts Distance Between Himself and Wife's Film Company
summary: Ethics watchdog had refused to certify Mnuchin's latest financial disclosures. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said this week he would recuse himself from any matter involving the film industry that could affect his wife's production company, after a government ethics watchdog refused to approve his most recent financial disclosures.

title: Harvard Investigates Fencing Coach's Financial Deal With a Parent
summary: Team official said to have sold his Massachusetts home for $989,500, nearly double its valuation. Harvard University is investigating its head fencing coach over financial transactions he made with the family of a current and a former student on the team, including a home sale shortly before the younger one applied to the school.

title: Ethiopian Initial Probe Blames 737 MAX Flight-Control System
summary: Preliminary report ratchets up pressure on Boeing to fix system. Air accident investigators found the cockpit crew of a crashed 737 MAX followed approved emergency procedures in an attempt to save the plane, ratcheting up pressure on Boeing Co. to fix a flight-control system at the heart of several probes into two deadly crashes of the airliner.

title: NYPD Investigating Whether Body Found in Storage Facility Is Missing Teacher
summary: Autopsy being done on charred remains; victim's husband named as suspect in vanishing. New York Police Department investigators are working to determine whether human remains found in a Staten Island storage facility Thursday are those of a missing teacher.

summary: Lawyers say that Cohen located documents believed to have 'significant value' to congressional investigators. WASHINGTON-Lawyers for Michael Cohen on Thursday sought lawmakers' help in efforts to obtain a reduced sentence for their client, a former lawyer for President Trump who is set to begin a three-year prison sentence next month.
